questions.text: Which is the most common type of anemia worldwide?
questions.solution:
The most common type of anaemia worldwide is iron deficiency anemia. It is also the most common type of nutritional anemia in India.

WHO recommendations for diagnosing anemia (g/dl) are:

Population Normal Mild Anemia Moderate Anemia Severe Anemia
Men ≥15 years ≥13 11 - 12.9 8 - 10.9 <8
Non-pregnant women ≥12 11 - 11.9 8 - 10.9 <8
Pregnant women ≥11 10 - 10.9 7 - 9.9 <7

questions.text: What is the most common hematologic manifestation seen in patients with HIV infection?
questions.solution:
Anaemia is the most common hematologic abnormality associated with HIV infection. It affects 60–80% of patients during the late stage.

In most cases, the cause of anaemia in HIV-infected patients is multifactorial. It is often associated with infection, inflammation, malignancy, malnutrition, and polypharmacy.

Note: Prior to the use of potent antiretroviral therapy (ART), thrombocytopenia was a common finding in individuals infected with HIV. With use of potent ART, the incidence of thrombocytopenia is far lower.

questions.text: Which of the following anemia is not due to diminished erythropoiesis?
questions.solution:
Hereditary spherocytosis is not due to diminished erythropoiesis. It is a type of hemolytic anemia.

Classification of anemia according to underlying mechanism:

  • Anemias of diminished erythropoiesis - decreased red cell production
  • Hemolytic anemias - increased red cell destruction
  • Anemia due to blood loss

Anemias due to diminished erythropoiesis:

  • Iron deficiency anemia
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Anemia of chronic diseases
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Myelophthisic anemia
  • Fanconi's anemia

questions.text: In a patient with MCV of 109 fl, which of the following is least likely?
questions.solution:
MCV >100 fl indicates macrocytic anaemia which is not seen in anaemia of chronic disease. RBCs in anemia of chronic disease are initially normocytic and normochromic, becoming microcytic and hypochromic over time.

Vitamin B12 deficiency, thiamine deficiency, and orotic aciduria cause macrocytic anaemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with iron deficiency anaemia is prescribed oral iron supplements. Foods containing which of the following can she take to increase its absorption?
questions.solution:
Absorption of iron is increased by ascorbic acid. It is decreased by phosphates, oxalates, and carbonates.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: Which of the following contains most of the functional iron in the body?
questions.solution:
Most of the functional iron (80%) in the body is found in hemoglobin. 

The storage pool represented by hemosiderin, and ferritin contains about 15% to 20% of total body iron. Myoglobin and iron-containing enzymes such as catalase and the cytochromes contain the rest.

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte.

Dietary iron is mostly in Fe3+ (ferric state) and must be reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous state) by ferrireductases. Fe2+ iron destined for circulation is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin 1.

Hephaestin is an iron oxidase that converts Fe2+ to Fe3+

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in iron metabolism?
questions.solution:
Ceruloplasmin is involved in iron metabolism.

Ferritin is the storage form of iron in the body. Ceruloplasmin and hephaestin help in oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ at the basolateral border of enterocytes. This is coupled with transport through ferroportin. In plasma, iron is transported by transferrin.

Haptocorrin and cubulin are involved in vitamin B12 absorption. Selenoprotein is involved in selenium metabolism.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to _____
questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin, which is an iron efflux channel in the enterocyte.

Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells (enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off.

Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:

  • Increased levels of iron
  • Inflammatory cytokines

Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors:

  • Iron deficiency
  • Hypoxia
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis

Hepcidin is encoded by the HAMP gene and its mutations are associated with hereditary hemochromatosis.

questions.text: What is the main site of iron absorption?
questions.solution:
Absorption of iron mainly occurs in the proximal duodenum.

Related Pearl: Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Duodenum + upper jejunum: Iron
  • Jejunum: Folate
  • Terminal Ileum: Vitamin B12

Mnemonic - Dude Is Just Feeling Ill Bro

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the internal iron homeostasis in iron-deficiency anaemia?

choices.text: Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases
Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Transferrin receptor 1 iron responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Ferritin mRNA concentration iron responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases

questions.solution:
In iron deficiency anaemia, there is an increase in transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis.

Iron absorbed through diet or which is released from circulation is bound to transferrin (iron transfer protein). When erythropoiesis is stimulated, iron-transferrin complexes act as transferrin receptors on the surface of bone marrow erythroid cells. Through receptor-mediated endocytosis, this complex is internalised. 

This iron is then made available for heme synthesis while the transferrin-receptor complex is recycled to the surface of the cell, from where the transferrin is released back into circulation and the transferrin receptor re-anchors into the cell membrane. The excess iron after hemoglobin synthesis binds to apoferritin (storage protein), forming ferritin. 

Senescent RBCs undergo phagocytosis in the cells of the reticuloendothelial system. The hemoglobin is broken down, the globin and other proteins are returned to the amino acid pool, and the iron is shuttled back to the surface of the reticuloendothelial cell, where it is taken up by transferrin via ferroportin (iron export channel).

There is no regulated excretory pathway for iron, and the only mechanisms by which iron is lost are blood loss (via gastrointestinal bleeding, menstruation, or other forms of bleeding) and the loss of epithelial cells from the skin, gut, and genitourinary tract. The normal daily iron loss from the body is 1-2 mg.

Variables Iron-deficient state  Iron-excess state
Iron uptake ↑ ↓
Transferrin receptor synthesis ↑ ↓
Transferrin receptor mRNA concentration ↑ ↓
Iron storage ↓ ↑
Ferritin synthesis ↓ ↑
Ferritin mRNA concentration No change No change

questions.text:
Peripheral smear of a patient with koilonychia is given below. Which of the following lab findings is consistent with her likely diagnosis?
Options S. ferritin TIBC Transferrin saturation
1 High Normal High
2 Normal Normal High
3 Low High Low
4 High Low Low
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear showing microcytic and hypochromic picture with pencil cells is suggestive of iron-deficiency anaemia. In this condition, TIBC is increased, transferrin saturation is decreased, and ferritin is decreased.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: You would expect iron-deficiency anaemia in all of the following patients except:

choices.text: A 54-year-old woman after Billroth II operation

questions.solution:
Maize rich diet is not one of the causes of iron deficiency anaemia. It can cause pellagra.

Iron deficiency anaemia can be caused by hookworm infestation, carcinoma of the cecum and in Billroth II operation.

Related Pearl: Causes of Iron Deficiency Anemia

Dietary lack

  • Infants, who are at high risk due to the very small amounts of iron in milk. Human breast milk provides only about 0.3 mg/L of iron.
  • The impoverished, who can have suboptimal diets for socioeconomic reasons at any age
  • Older adults, who often have restricted diets with little meat because of limited income or poor dentition
  • Teenagers, who subsist on junk food

Impaired absorption

  • Sprue
  • Gastrectomy (Billroth II surgery)

Increased requirement

  • Growing infants, children, and adolescents
  • Premenopausal women, particularly during pregnancy.
  • Economically deprived women having multiple, closely spaced pregnancies are at exceptionally high risk.

Chronic blood loss

  • Menorrhagia
  • Carcinoma of the cecum
  • Hookworm infestation

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings is seen in a patient with sideroblastic anaemia?
questions.solution:
In sideroblastic anemia, the transferrin saturation is increased.

Serum iron and serum ferritin are also elevated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the triad of the Plummer-Vinson syndrome?
questions.solution:
The triad of the Plummer-Vinson syndrome does not include koilonychia (marked as 2).

Triad of Plummer–Vinson syndrome:

  • Esophageal webs
  • Microcytic hypochromic anaemia
  • Atrophic glossitis

Koilonychia is a symptom of iron deficiency anaemia. It may or may not be present in Plummer Vinson syndrome. Hence, it is not a part of the triad.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with severe anaemia was started on parenteral iron. Which of the following would occur first in this patient as a response to therapy?
questions.solution:
One of the earliest responses to the correction of iron deficiency anaemia is increase in serum iron. 

Responses after initiation of treatment:

  • 12 to 24 hours - Replenishment of intracellular iron enzymes; decreased irritability; increased appetite; increase in serum iron.
  • 36 to 48 hours - Erythroid hyperplasia in bone marrow 
  • 48 to 72 hours - Reticulocytosis, peaking at 5-7 days
  • 4 to 30 days - Increase in hemoglobin level, increase in ferritin, increase in MCV
  • 1 to 3 months - Repletion of stores
